title: Audiologic Management of a Patient with Psychogenic Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: My supervisor is concerned about my difficulty communicating with customers in person and over the phone. I am afraid my job is in jeopardy because coworkers say I can't follow instructions.

problem_summary.onset: Approximately 2 months ago (based on coworker complaints).
problem_summary.course: Worsening; initial evaluation showed mild-moderate loss, re-evaluation 2 months later showed significant decrease in sensitivity.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Anxiety, history of high blood pressure. Denies tinnitus, vertigo, or head trauma.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Work performance issues; difficulty following instructions; asking people to repeat portions of conversations.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Referral by GP due to fear of job loss; obtained medical clearance for hearing aids.

history.present_illness: Patient referred by GP due to work difficulties. Reports asking for repetitions. Medical history positive for childhood middle ear pathology.
history.otologic_history: No recent illness, trauma, or tinnitus.
history.medical_psych_history: Taking prescription medication for anxiety and high blood pressure.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild to moderate SNHL in the right ear; slight to mild SNHL in the left ear. Asymmetric configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs commensurate with PTA. WRS indicated slight difficulty at 80 dB HL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear pressure and static admittance bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes. Obtained at reduced sensation levels (suspicious for non-organic or cochlear recruitment). No decay observed.

history.present_illness: Patient returned 2 months later for hearing aid fitting. Medical clearance obtained. Negative physical exam and imaging by otologist.
history.prior_management: Selected for BTE hearing aids; earmold impressions previously taken.
history.patient_goals: Hearing aid fitting (initially), then further investigation due to threshold shift.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Significant decrease in hearing sensitivity compared to V1. Now mild to moderate SNHL bilaterally. Left ear dropped significantly.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs shifted by 10 dB or greater. WRS showed moderate difficulty in Right ear, slight in Left.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Normal absolute and interwave latencies. Wave V repeatable down to low levels, indicating normal neural integrity and sensitivity better than behavioral thresholds.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAE)
tests.key_findings: Present and repeatable normal amplitudes at most frequencies (1000-6000 Hz), inconsistent with the moderate hearing loss indicated by behavioral audiometry.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient initially presented with asymmetric mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss which appeared to worsen significantly upon re-evaluation two months later. However, objective electrophysiological measures (ABR and DPOAE) obtained during the second visit revealed normal cochlear and retrocochlear function, with ABR thresholds (15-25 dB HL) significantly better than the voluntary behavioral thresholds (45-50 dB HL). These findings are consistent with pseudohypacusis (non-organic hearing loss).
counseling_points: We have completed a detailed set of tests today, including some that measure your hearing nerve's automatic response to sound.
The results from the automatic tests (ABR and OAEs) show that your inner ear and hearing nerve are actually working within the normal range.
There is a discrepancy between the results where you pushed the button and the results from the automatic tests.
Based on these objective findings, your hearing sensitivity is better than what was observed during the behavioral hearing test.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is anxious about job security.
During behavioral testing (tone pressing), be consistent within the session, but your thresholds should be elevated (mild-moderate loss) despite having normal hearing.
Do not act like a 'malingerer' with obvious exaggeration; your responses should be reliable but simply at the wrong level.
If asked about the discrepancy, express confusion or lack of realization that the responses were inconsistent.
